Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: They have a generous deadline and can refactor the module later
Story: I walk through the door, laptop bag slung over my shoulder, and immediately sense the heaviness in the room. My boyfriend sits on the couch, shoulders slumped, eyes fixed on the floor. He barely looks up as I enter. I know that look—he’s had a rough day. I want to drop everything, sit beside him, and listen, to be the supportive girlfriend he needs right now. But my mind is tangled in lines of code. I’ve been thinking all day about the module I’m working on, how I could finally refactor it now that the deadline isn’t breathing down my neck. It’s the perfect time to make the code cleaner, more efficient, and I’ve been itching to dive in. Yet, here he is, needing me. I feel the pull in both directions—my heart aches for him, but my mind races with solutions for my code. I stand in the hallway, torn, laptop still in hand, unsure which role to step into first.
